entry.title: The Subtle Art of Always Quitting Your Hobbies
entry.summary: So, it's been a while. Where do I start? Let’s start at the beginning. I’ve been writing for most of my life. As a kid, I wrote stories, though they never went beyond a few pages. I even started a neighborhood newspaper, but that didn’t last long. I wrote about football matches during big tournaments like the World Cup, but once the tournament ended, so did my writing. Not that I felt really sad about that, by the way. Most of the time I was glad it was over, because I could finally stop the forced writing. I also wrote for a fairly big gaming website for a couple of years, but I always dreaded writing long reviews. Enjoyment was far away. Then, in June of this year, I rediscovered my love for writing — this time, on my personal blog. I found a community of fellow writers on Mastodon and r…

entry.title: Trump, The Purge, Black Nazis and the Language of Apocalyptic Lies and Violence
entry.summary: At a campaign rally in Erie, Pennsylvania, Trump invoked a chilling convergence of law, order, and violence—a cornerstone of what can only be described as his politics of disposability. By referencing The Purge, a dystopian film where the government legalizes all forms of violence, including murder, for 12 hours, Trump escalates his rhetoric to a dangerous metaphor. In his hands, “the purge” becomes more than just a narrative device; it embodies a vision in which state-sanctioned violence reaches its grotesque climax. More The post Trump, The Purge, Black Nazis and the Language of Apocalyptic Lies and Violence appeared first on CounterPunch.org.

entry.title: turning a bearblog into a microblog
entry.summary: Since Robert Birming released his Timeline design, I've been playing around with it and including it in some of my pages. But I was also curious on how I could include it to make a microblog out of a typical Bearblog. Not that you can't make short posts on here in a default look, but most of the design of Bearblog and its themes is decidedly for longform content. I wanted something that looks more like a microblogging/short post platform. ==Some goals I had in mind for my own microblog:== I didn't want these low effort posts to be in the Discovery section; make_discoverable has to be false in the Post preset. The posts need to mention when they were made; I need to include {{ post_published_date }} in the h4 of the Timeline code. I want the main page you land on to display the most recent …

entry.title: The Art You Cannot See
entry.summary:
When I was a child, I grew up in a hoarder home. My mother had me at 16. We lived with my grandmother and her then wife, who kept everything she ever received. I have vivid memories of two things in that house. The first is the kitchen table. There were no chairs around the table, it was never used to eat meals. Instead it was filled to the edges with things left unused.
The second was the piano. It was old, out of tune. The wood was peeling and no one in the home knew how to play the instrument. It sat in the front of the house and I was the only one to ever touch it. Like the table, the top of the piano was a menagerie of unwanted items and dust. I would toy around on it, pressing the keys down and creating out of tune melodies that have been lost to time.
When I was 11, my mother …

entry.title: Our Homeowners Association Saga
entry.summary: I've lived in neighborhoods with a Homeowners Association1 all my life. There were times I found having one to be advantageous, but these days it's just plain annoying. The house I grew up in had an HOA. You could tell that the neighborhood had an HOA because our neighborhood was the typical-ish middle class cul-des-sac neighborhood. It was surrounded by a huge man-made pond that was well kept, with a park that got upgraded throughout the years. It used to be an orchard that became what it is today. As far as I knew, there were no strict rules enforced by our HOA. I'm assuming the money went to the upkeep of that pond and park, and little things around the neighborhood. When I bought my first house in 2012, that house also had an HOA. The fees were super minimal, and I paid once a year. Th…

entry.title: Announcing the 2024 Steering Committee Election Results
entry.summary: The 2024 Steering Committee Election is now complete. The Kubernetes Steering Committee consists of 7 seats, 3 of which were up for election in 2024. Incoming committee members serve a term of 2 years, and all members are elected by the Kubernetes Community. This community body is significant since it oversees the governance of the entire Kubernetes project. With that great power comes great responsibility. You can learn more about the steering committee’s role in their charter. Thank you to everyone who voted in the election; your participation helps support the community’s continued health and success. Results Congratulations to the elected committee members whose two year terms begin immediately (listed in alphabetical order by GitHub handle): Antonio Ojea (@aojea), Google Benjamin Elde…

entry.title: Understanding multilingual token compression in GPT-o family models
entry.summary:
Disclaimer: I wrote this article before OpenAI released o1, which now hides its "reasoning" tokens making them inaccessible through the tiktoken library. I think o1 uses the same base tokenizer as GPT-o, but unfortunately we can no longer observe this directly. GPT-o introduces a new tokenizer o200k_base, which both doubles the model's vocabulary size to 200k (previously 100k with GPT-4) and significantly improves token compression, especially for non-English tokens.
Source: GPT-o release Compression For non-Latin scripts, o200k_base achieves significantly higher token compression compared to GPT-4's c100k_base, demonstrating more efficient word tokenization. For example, looking at the Tamil sentence நீ எப்படி இருக்கிறாய்? நான் நல்லா இருக்கேன். (translation: How are you? I am fine.), c10…

entry.title: Notes on Sufic Rewilding
entry.summary: Dawah Inc is dying. Tumblr e-girl intrigue, the notoriety of public celebrity, the psy-slop of attention hacking economics and industrial scale mediocrity is tearing down the aura, prestige and myth of Islamicate civilization in cyber. The latent iconoclastic potential of Islamicate art has been squandered and instead we have meatspace media empires, fools who have tried to make gold off the back of other fools. In the process we have a contagion of functional illiteracy, cultural apocalypse and no real vibrancy. The Muhammadan spirit is missing from Dawah Inc. There is no real transgression, when Dawah Inc positions itself as a menu item that also includes Ben Shapiro and Jordan Peterson. There must be consideration for what comes next. Part of what must come next, must grasp the iconocla…

entry.title: A Day in Carmel-by-the-Sea, CA
entry.summary:
Carmel by the Sea is such a cute little town—super quaint and dog-friendly! We spent the day here for my birthday back in August. Already trying to figure out when we can go again to continue exploring since we didn't get a chance to do the Fairy Tale Houses tour. Thankfully walking around town was a fairy tale in itself.
There were a ton of cute alleyways like this.
One of the libraries we visited so I could sign up for a library card to add to my collection.
Here's another library. Unfortunately we didn't go inside to get a library card here.
Plenty of artwork gems to discover like this.
and this.
We event found a nice little dog shop where we almost bought a bag for Cocoa.
🎂 Related (Birthday Weekend Series): San Francisco in a Frame Incoming Fog Down the PCH An August Morning

entry.summary: Discover how Capital One uses Web NFC to authenticate customers on Android mobile devices.

entry.title: Exposure to Generative AI and Expectations About Inequality
entry.summary: With the rise of generative AI (genAI) tools such as ChatGPT, many worry about the tools’ potential displacement effects in the labor market and the implications for income inequality. In supplemental questions to the February 2024 Survey of Consumer Expectations (SCE), we asked a representative sample of U.S. residents about their experience with genAI tools. We find that relatively few people have used genAI, but that those who have used it have a bleaker outlook on its impacts on jobs and future inequality.

entry.title: How Cloudflare auto-mitigated world record 3.8 Tbps DDoS attack
entry.summary: Over the past couple of weeks, Cloudflare's DDoS protection systems have automatically and successfully mitigated multiple hyper-volumetric L3/4 DDoS attacks exceeding 3 billion packets per second (Bpps). Our systems also automatically mitigated multiple attacks exceeding 3 terabits per second (Tbps), with the largest ones exceeding 3.65 Tbps. The scale of these attacks is unprecedented.

entry.title: The Calm Before the Storm
entry.summary: At the time of writing this post, Typhoon Krathon will hit the populated west side of Taiwan in four hours. I was feeling rather cooped up earlier so I went out for a walk. Smack in the pouring rain. Thankfully, my sneakers were worn and in need of replacing so getting them soaked wasn't the biggest deal; still, one is forced to ask oneself if they're capable of making good life decisions when the wind starts howling against your umbrella. By the time I got to the halfway point of my walk, lightning was flashing furiously. Like I said, not a good life decision. Almost every store was closed today. The only things left running were big corporate: convenience stores and chain cafes. I stopped by a Louisa (Taiwan's Starbucks equivalent) and saw that there was only the barista inside. I asked …

entry.title: PRC 75 today
entry.summary:
Today is the 75th anniversary of the founding of the People's Republic of China (PRC). The survival of the PRC is now longer than the Soviet Union, which lasted 74 years. China has nearly one-fifth of the world's population and on some measures is the largest economy in the world, although per person national income is only 30% of that of the US. English

entry.title: Are Nonbank Financial Institutions Systemic?
entry.summary: Recent events have heightened awareness of systemic risk stemming from nonbank financial sectors. For example, during the COVID-19 pandemic, liquidity demand from nonbank financial entities caused a “dash for cash” in financial markets that required government support. In this post, we provide a quantitative assessment of systemic risk in the nonbank sectors. Even though these sectors have heterogeneous business models, ranging from insurance to trading and asset management, we find that their systemic risk has common variation, and this commonality has increased over time. Moreover, nonbank sectors tend to become more systemic when banking sector systemic risk increases.

author.name: Andres Aradillas Fernandez, Martin Hiti, and Asani Sarkar

entry.title: Impact of Verizon’s September 30 outage on Internet traffic
entry.summary: On Monday, September 30, customers on Verizon’s mobile network in multiple cities across the United States reported experiencing a loss of connectivity. HTTP request traffic data from Verizon’s mobile ASN (AS6167) showed nominal declines across impacted cities.

entry.title: Goodbye, Cohost
entry.summary: Alright, I'm a little sick, and I have something of a headache, and I'm emotional for more reasons than just Cohost, but here goes. I've been writing on the internet for most of the time that I've been alive. I've done it on blogs, I've done it on social media. I've done it for money and I've done it for free. I've done it on Tumblr and on more than one defunct media vertical and in interactive fiction. Cohost was the first place where it felt like, consistently, someone was always reading. Something about the site's design and user culture created a magical space where people approached things with openness and curiosity and willingness to give their time and attention. This felt like a place where you could write about anything and people would care. I've talked about the Put your Helmet…

entry.title: been thinking about tangible reality
entry.summary: this post was originally written for the final couple days of cohost, a long-form social media site that as of october 1st will be sunsetting. it really is precious, sometimes. to look at something and be able to experience it with your senses. it's novel, most days. you just do it without thinking. but then there's times when you experience an intangible unreality so strong that it becomes a force in your life that can't be measured. we don't have scales for that, or weights that add up the unreal intangible space that exists between little lights in a grid & your brain. there is a space, somewhere within the imagination, that fills in bit by bit over time. like reading a book, making the world come to life, hearing voices, making up the parts that the author never tells you. internet spa…

entry.title: Timeline
entry.summary: My Timeline Atomic Age Alexandra was born at a very young age, in Germany, to English speaking parents, which confused the hell out of her. Three Years Later At aged 3, Alexandra took a very long boat journey with her parents half way around the world, from England to Hong Kong, via South Africa, and never once got sea sick. Three Years Later Having survived an earthquake, a 1000 year historic tsunami that lifted a ship out of the harbour, and a mega typhoon that sucked all the windows out of their third story apartment, Alexandra and her family flew back to England for tea and marmalade sandwiches. Three Years Later After the heat and humidity of SE Asia, Alexandra and her family spent 3 years shivering in the cold frozen north of Scotland eating a lot of fish and chips. She did, however, get to sit in an English Electric Lightning fighter jet, and has the photographic evidence to prove it. Three Years Later What seemed like months but was, in fact, only days, Alexandra and her family arrived, by plane, in Singapore. Having hopped, skipped, and seemingly, jumped, through various countries. Singapore was very similar to Hong Kong minus the earthquake. It did, however, have a lot of tropical fish which Alexandra enjoyed collecting. Three Years Later Arriving back in England, on a fancy jet, Alexandra and her family settled back into a boring English life where, secretly, they all longed to be back in SE Asia, anywhere, but the north of England. Whereupon, Alexandra quietly waited for adulthood to arrive. Six Years Later Having waited patiently for adulthood to arrive, Alexandra packed a marmite sandwich, her toothbrush, favourite teddy bear, and a lucky button wrapped in a ten shilling note and, like Nelly the elephant, ran away to join the circus. Also known as, at this time, the Women's Royal Air Force. Where she became an air traffic controller, as it is also known, air is notoriously difficult to control at any given time of the day or night.

entry.title: The Central Banking Beauty Contest
entry.summary: Expectations can play a significant role in driving economic outcomes, with central banks factoring market sentiment into policy decisions and market participants forming their own assumptions about monetary policy. But how well do central banks understand the expectations of market participants—and vice versa? Our model, developed in a recent paper, features a dynamic game between (i) a monetary authority that cannot commit to an inflation target and (ii) a set of market participants that understand the incentives created by that credibility problem. In this post, we describe the game, a type of Keynesian beauty contest: its main novelty is that each side attempts, with varying degrees of accuracy, to forecast the other’s beliefs, resulting in new findings regarding the levels and trajectories of inflation.

entry.title: Spotlight on CNCF Deaf and Hard-of-hearing Working Group (DHHWG)
entry.summary: In recognition of Deaf Awareness Month and the importance of inclusivity in the tech community, we are spotlighting Catherine Paganini, facilitator and one of the founding members of CNCF Deaf and Hard-of-Hearing Working Group (DHHWG). In this interview, Sandeep Kanabar, a deaf member of the DHHWG and part of the Kubernetes SIG ContribEx Communications team, sits down with Catherine to explore the impact of the DHHWG on cloud native projects like Kubernetes. Sandeep’s journey is a testament to the power of inclusion. Through his involvement in the DHHWG, he connected with members of the Kubernetes community who encouraged him to join SIG ContribEx - the group responsible for sustaining the Kubernetes contributor experience. In an ecosystem where open-source projects are actively seeking co…

entry.title: Comrade President? Change and Continuity in Sri Lanka
entry.summary:
Anura Kumara Dissanayake's (AKD) victory on 21 September as the candidate of the centre-left National People's Power (NPP) coalition is highly significant for symbolic and substantive reasons. His predecessors have been from the social and political elite that has mis-ruled Sri Lanka since independence from Britain in 1948. Some were born into that elite, while a couple (Ranasinghe Premadasa, Maithripala Sirisena) made their way into it through the business of politics before they occupied (...) English
/ Austerity/Structural Adjustment, Sri Lanka, IMF, Debt crisis

entry.title: Nihil: Embracing Digital Minimalism
entry.summary:
In a world of endless notifications, feature-bloated apps, and constant digital noise, I found myself yearning for simplicity. That's why I created Nihil - a suite of minimalist tools designed to help you focus on what truly matters. The Vision Behind Nihil Nihil was born out of a personal need. As a developer and a user, I was frustrated with the complexity of many digital tools. I wanted something that would strip away the unnecessary and leave only the essential. Something that would help me think clearer and live more intentionally. That's the core of Nihil's philosophy: less is more. Each tool in the Nihil suite serves a single, specific purpose. No bloat, no distractions - just pure functionality.
What Makes Nihil Different? Purposeful Design Every feature in Nihil is there because …
